Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Functional Genomics and Physiological Ecology of Seasonal Succession in Antarctic Phytoplankton: Adaptations to Light and Temperature
Award.AbstractNarration: The proposed research will investigate the genomic basis of the physiological and ecological transition of Antarctic marine phytoplankton from a cold dark winter to a warmer, brighter spring. During a field season at Palmer Station, functional genomics (using next generation sequencing technology to identify expressed genes) and in situ fluorometry (FRRF) will be integrated with classical ecological methods to investigate photosynthetic adaptation during phytoplankton species succession from late winter into spring. Using large data sets, this project will test whether amino acid usages differ based on expression. The specific objectives are (1) To characterize phytoplankton succession from the winter to spring transition, and (2) To correlate community gene expression profiles to adaptational differences among taxa. Broader impacts include training of a post doctoral researcher and two undergraduate science majors, with efforts to attract students from underrepresented groups. The P.I.s also will prepare presentations for the public, regarding research experiences, research results, and the importance of climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Phytoplankton are microscopic photosynthetic algae that form the base of marine food webs in all of the Earth’s oceans, even the freezing waters of polar regions (Figure 1). These organisms represent a significant portion of the carbon biomass in the sea; and in addition to providing energy (i.e., a food source) for other organisms, phytoplankton produce a significant amount of the oxygen found in the atmosphere - the oxygen required to sustain life on our planet. Understanding how phytoplankton respond to changes in their environment is a key aspect of understanding nature. The Southern Ocean plays a significant role in the global carbon cycle and has a major influence on global climate. The aim of this project was to evaluate changes in Antarctic phytoplankton gene expression relative to changes in the environment, specifically seasonal (winter-spring) gradients of light and temperature in Antarctica (Figure 2). The winter-spring transition in temperature provided an ideal situation to observe the role of warming on physiological processes in the phytoplankton community. The ultimate goal of this project is to better understand the seasonal changes that occur in polar phytoplankton productivity and to evaluate potential responses of phytoplankton to continued climate change.

Photosynthesis requires sunlight and polar regions have extreme fluctuations in light across the year. During a 4-month field season from winter to spring (Aug-Nov 2011) at Palmer Station (Antarctic Peninsula), we documented temporal patterns in 1) a variety of environmental parameters (e.g., water temperature, salinity, light, nutrients) in the water column (0-60 m depth), 2) the taxonomic structure of the phytoplankton community, and 3) levels of gene expression in order to investigate the molecular basis of ecological responses of Antarctic marine phytoplankton during the seasonal change from a cold dark winter to a warmer brighter spring. Additional laboratory experiments were completed with cultures of individual species to determine differential responses to the same environmental conditions and augment the field work.

Light intensity, day length and water temperature increased during the study period. Sea ice conditions were very variable over the four months, an important factor as surface ice blocks light needed for photosynthesis. The study period coincided with the annual Antarctic springtime ozone depletion cycle that results in higher levels of ultraviolet exposure for organisms in Antarctica. All of these changing environmental conditions caused continual alteration of the phytoplankton community and species concentrations changed over time (species succession). An unexpected observation was the nearly complete dominance of one species, Corethron pennatum by the end of October, indicating that this species was able to compete better than other phytoplankton species for available light and nutrients, allowing it to grow and multiple at a much faster rate. During the “bloom” formation we were able to document details about many aspects of the life cycle of Corethron.

Examination of gene expression has revealed distinct patterns of co-regulated genes (ie., when multiple genes respond in the same way) related to 1) basic cellular process (e.g., growth, cell division), as well as 2) physiological responses to environmental stress (e.g., seasonal changes in temperature, increased UVB from ozone depletion events). Of particular interest was the observation that gene expression can be quantified on very short time scales of hours and can have distinct daily fluctuations. These observations provide significant insights for gauging the effects of current and predicted climate change on Antarctic marine phytoplankton communities
